tr.td: int[] nums = new int[10];
Declares and instantiates an array of 10 int values called nums

int[] nums;
nums = new int[10];
Same thing except using two statements
SmileyFace[] smiles = new SmileyFace[5];
Declares and instantiates an array of 5 SmileyFace objects called smiles

SmileyFace[] smiles
smiles = new SmileyFace[5];
Same thing except using two statements

page.h2: Examples of putting values into arrays:

tr.td: nums[0] = 5;
Puts the number 5 into the 1st element of the nums array
Calculates 10 * 6 - 3 and puts the result into the 1st element of the nums array
smiles[0] = new SmileyFace(10, 50, 100, Color.BLUE, null);
Instantiates a new SmileyFace object and puts a reference to it into the 1st element of the smiles array
Puts the number 125 into index 4 of the nums array (which is really the 5th element)

int i = 4;
nums[i] = 125;
Same as above except uses a variable for the index number. VERY POWERFUL!
nums[nums.length-1] = 256;
Puts the number 256 into the last element of the nums array

page.h2: Examples of accessing values in arrays:

tr.td: System.out.println(nums[0]);
Prints the int that is stored in the 1st element of the nums array
System.out.println(nums[3]);
Prints the int that is stored in at index 3 in the nums array (which is really the 4th element)
System.out.println(nums[nums.length-1]);
Prints the int that is stored in the last element of the nums array
System.out.println(smiles[1]);
Goes to the SmileyFace object referenced by index 1 of the smiles array (the 2nd element), calls the .toString() method on it, and sends the return value to println().

nums.length;
smiles.length;

Represents the number of elements in an array.
Note that the last element of an array is .length-1 since the indexes start at 0.
Also note: This is not standard. Standard practice would expose a method to do this, and it would end with empty parentheses. .length on an array is an old part of the language that doesn't adhere to standards.
